Task #725: Transform SEIs from/to JSON

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need the prop order? I thought the XmlID tag makes the structuralElementInstance property first in line?
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -38,6 +52,10 @@
  * @author fisc_ph
  *
  */
+@XmlAccessorType(XmlAccessType.NONE)
+@XmlRootElement
+// Ensure that the sei (by uuid) gets unmarshalled first
+@XmlType(propOrder = {"structuralElementInstance", "name", "parentSeiBean", "categoryAssignments", "children", "superSeis"})

replies.bodyText: Good question, I know for a fact that it doesn't work if I delete that line atm. But I will investigate it.
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

replies.bodyText:
Ok so I looked into it and the documentation says nothing about changing the order if using @XmlID, instead it can be used together with @XmlIDREF to model reference and containment.
So for testing I uncommented the Annotation in ABeanObject and it didn't have any effect. The reason that it gets unmarshalled first in ABeanObject actually is the naming of the method: "getATypeInstance" which is handled as "aTypeInstance" field and so is first alphabetically ordered. So we could either rename the method or use the propOrder (for which all properties have to be listed). FYI: the only available order are alphabetically or unordered, so this won't help either.
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

timeline.bodyText:
There seems to be some inconsistency between using the abstract classes and the generic classes.
E.g. the getChildren uses the abstract class for seis and the getCategoryAssignments uses the generic class.
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR

replies.bodyText: I added comments, why we do this
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR

timeline.bodyText: Using the abstract bean class in the interface declaration seems weird to me... Maybe we can consistently use the IBeanStructuralElementInstance everywhere?
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -104,6 +105,18 @@
 	 */
 	<SEI_TYPE extends IBeanStructuralElementInstance> List<SEI_TYPE> getChildren(Class<SEI_TYPE> beanSeiClazz);
 	
+	/**
+	 * This method hands back all child Bean wrapped StructuralElementInstances of the abstract type ABeanStructuralElementInstance
+	 * @return all children which could be found in the current Bean SEI
+	 */
+	List<ABeanStructuralElementInstance> getChildren();

replies.bodyText: As we talked about, we can't easily

timeline.bodyText: Please wwrite some comment to mention what the intention of the test is.
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

timeline.bodyText: They are the same because they are compared by their internal type instance?
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

timeline.bodyText: What does the adapterNoRs stand for?
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: It means an adapter that is initilized without a resource set. I will rename it to adapterWithoutResourceSet to make it clear
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

timeline.bodyText: Rs NoRs stands for Adapter with ResourceSet and Adapter without?
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

timeline.bodyText:
We should be aware, that the list we are handing back, does not allow to directly add a CA to the SEI, since it is realy just a pure List of CAs. I think it is ok in case that we are clear on the API contract.
Do we want to have it like this, since operations such as Bean.getCategoryAssignments().add(CA) will not add a CA to the Bean.
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: After discussion with @SaMuellerDLR we think the returned list should be wrapped to an unmodifiable collection if posible. This would be in line with the contract of all the other metods to get all CAs which are internalley calling the BeanStructuralElementInstanceHelper.
replies.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText:
That makes sense I will wrapp it into an unmodifiable collection
Ok so I looked into it and I saw that I also had to break the contract in the other getters (cast the unmodifiable list to an array list). The reason is the following: When unmarshalling JAXB internally calls the getter and then calls add to the list. This doesn't work if the list is unmodifiable. I actually don't see a way to unmarshall these lists without breaking the contract. I think I also had some discussion with @SaMuellerDLR in which we didn't find a solution.
This JAXB behavior has already caused a lot problems and the current solution only works because the underlying EList ignore duplicates.
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

replies.bodyText: Now JAXB doesn't use the functions of the interface, but instead some private functions shadowing the behavior. This way the original functions can return unmodifiable lists.
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

timeline.bodyText: Is it neccessary to use EList, would List work as well?
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: I will change it to List
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

timeline.bodyText: Isn't it possible to directly use the BeanCategoryAssignmentHelper by calling getAllBeanCategories(sei, ABeanCategoryAssignment.class) here?
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: I don't see the advantage, because we use BeanCategoryAssignment here and not ABeanCategoryAssignment. Or do you want to change the contract to ABeanCategoryAssignment? If I remember correctly we use BeanCategoryAssignment  because there were some problems in the set method when using the abstract class instead.
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

timeline.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: I will change it to List
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR

timeline.bodyText: SInce it is instantiating the IUuidAdadapter the null check on the resourceSet above could be removed, it will be done in the IUuidAdapter anyway, doesn't it?
timeline.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: You are right, i will also remove it in ABeanObjectAdapter
replies.author: JAmmermann-DLR
